description:
In 2046, a revolutionary 80% shock-absorbing reinforced cardboard has been developed, rapidly transforming the world's exports. The reinforced cardboard would soon become the battleground for a popular children's hobby called "LBX" (Little Battler eXperience).

Four years later, a boy named Yamano Ban who loves to play with LBX (although without a mecha himself) is given a case containing the model AX-00 by a mysterious woman. He is told that he now holds the hopes and despairs of mankind in his hands.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Terrorism
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a terrorist or terrorist organization.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Cute Girls Doing Cute Things
tags.description: Centers around female characters doing cute activities, usually with little to no emphasis on drama and conflict.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/AkihiroHino)

A video game designer. Started his career as a programmer in the late '80s, and later took on roles in writing, designing, directing and producing. In 1998, he founded Level-5, a Japanese video game studio, where he remains its president and CEO.

Known for titles such as Dark Cloud, Dark Chronicle, Inazuma Eleven and Professor Layton.
He is a professional screenwriter for anime, drama and theater and is a member of the Writers Guild of Japan.
He is a professional screenwriter for anime, drama and theater and is a member of the Writers Guild of Japan.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sunma47) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/三間雅文)

One of the industry's most prolific sound directors, having worked on more than 300 productions.

After having graduated college, Mima joined Magic Capsule, a sound production company ran by his relative [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062/). In 1986, he debuted as a sound director on [MD Geist](https://anilist.co/anime/1285/MD-Geist/). He left Magic Capsule in 1996, and later joined Techno Sound. In 2004, he became the studio's representative director.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/325492584) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=tatsuya_yoshihara)

Freelance animator formerly affiliated with [Actas](https://anilist.co/studio/60/) where he was attending its internal animation school and debuted as animator at the age of 20. His work has been greatly influenced by contemporary Kanada school animators [Seiya Numata](https://anilist.co/staff/124320/) and [Hironori Tanaka](https://anilist.co/staff/103979/). 

He's a precocious talent, debuting as episode director at the age of 21 and as director at the age of 23 with [Arve Rezzle](https://anilist.co/anime/13863/), as part of the Young Animator Training Project.

Married to fellow animator [Kikuko Sadakata](https://anilist.co/staff/105769).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西村博之_(イラストレーター%29)

Originating from [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西村博之_(イラストレーター%29)
